dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A listener, Mark from Chicago, writes in: "After that wild week, is the tech rebound for real or just a dead cat bounce?"
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A listener, Mark from Chicago, writes in: After that wild week, is the tech rebound for real or just a dead cat bounce?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh man, that's the million-dollar question. I mean, the Nasdaq did jump 2.1% on Thursday, which is huge after falling into correction territory.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh man, that's the million-dollar question. I mean, the Nasdaq did jump two point one percent on Thursday, which is huge after falling into correction territory.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 1.6%, around 450 points, on Wednesday, while the S&P 500 rose 1.8% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite gained 1.9%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and we saw some of those big names like Microsoft and Amazon actually move higher, which is a relief after how brutal Tuesday was.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and we saw some of those big names like Microsoft and Amazon actually move higher, which is a relief after how brutal Tuesday was.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tech stocks rebounded somewhat, a day after the Nasdaq fell into correction territory, with shares of Microsoft, Amazon, Facebook and Google-parent Alphabet all moving higher.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but then you've got Adam Crisafulli from Vital Knowledge saying, uh, these bounces right now should be sold, not chased. He thinks sentiment isn't conducive to a sustainable bottom yet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but then you've got Adam Crisafulli from Vital Knowledge saying, uh, these bounces right now should be sold, not chased. He thinks sentiment isn't conducive to a sustainable bottom yet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If anything, sentiment around tech isnt conducive to forming a sustainable bottom with most people asking when (not if) the group should be bought as a result, bounces right now should be sold, not chased.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: That's a really sobering point. And it's not like everything was up—Lululemon and Slack both took pretty big hits despite good earnings, which is confusing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a really sobering point. And it's not like everything was up-Lululemon and Slack both took pretty big hits despite good earnings, which is confusing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Despite both companies reporting better-than-expected corporate earnings, shares of athletic retailer Lululemon and workplace messaging platform Slack fell more than 7% and 14%, respectively.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And then there's the whole AstraZeneca vaccine pause—you'd think that would spook people, but investors just shrugged it off this time.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And then there's the whole AstraZeneca vaccine pause-you'd think that would spook people, but investors just shrugged it off this time.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investors also shrugged off a setback with AstraZeneca and Oxfords late-stage coronavirus vaccine, which has now been put on hold due to a patient in the U.K. coming down with a mysterious illness.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild how resilient the market can seem one day and then so fragile the next. Like, Tesla surged over 6% on Wednesday after its worst day ever.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild how resilient the market can seem one day and then so fragile the next. Like, Tesla surged over six percent on Wednesday after its worst day ever.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Teslas stock, which had its worst day ever on Tuesdayfalling 21% after being snubbed from the S&P 500 index, rose over 5% on Wednesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, a 22% drop in one day—that's just insane volatility. And Apple bouncing back over 3% after dropping 15% in three sessions? It's a rollercoaster.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, a twenty two percent drop in one day-that's just insane volatility. And Apple bouncing back over three percent after dropping fifteen percent in three sessions? It's a rollercoaster.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Teslas stock, which had its worst day ever on Tuesdayfalling 21% after being snubbed from the S&P 500 index, rose over 5% on Wednesday. Shares of Apple, which fell 14% in the previous three sessions, also rebounded on Wednesday, gaining over 3%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And you know, even with all this, some people are making fortunes—like that Elon Musk of China regaining billionaire status with a 472% stock surge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And you know, even with all this, some people are making fortunes-like that Elon Musk of China regaining billionaire status with a four hundred seventy two percent stock surge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Elon Musk Of China Regains Billionaire Status With 472% Stock Surge

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, talk about a comeback story. But overall, it feels like we're not out of the woods yet with tech.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, talk about a comeback story. But overall, it feels like we're not out of the woods yet with tech.

artist_script:
HostA: A listener, Mark from Chicago, writes in: "After that wild week, is the tech rebound for real or just a dead cat bounce?"
HostB: Oh man, that's the million-dollar question. I mean, the Nasdaq did jump 2.1% on Thursday, which is huge after falling into correction territory.
HostA: Right, and we saw some of those big names like Microsoft and Amazon actually move higher, which is a relief after how brutal Tuesday was.
HostB: Yeah, but then you've got Adam Crisafulli from Vital Knowledge saying, uh, these bounces right now should be sold, not chased. He thinks sentiment isn't conducive to a sustainable bottom yet.
HostA: That's a really sobering point. And it's not like everything was up—Lululemon and Slack both took pretty big hits despite good earnings, which is confusing.
HostB: Exactly. And then there's the whole AstraZeneca vaccine pause—you'd think that would spook people, but investors just shrugged it off this time.
HostA: It's wild how resilient the market can seem one day and then so fragile the next. Like, Tesla surged over 6% on Wednesday after its worst day ever.
HostB: Yeah, a 22% drop in one day—that's just insane volatility. And Apple bouncing back over 3% after dropping 15% in three sessions? It's a rollercoaster.
HostA: For sure. And you know, even with all this, some people are making fortunes—like that Elon Musk of China regaining billionaire status with a 472% stock surge.
HostB: Wow, talk about a comeback story. But overall, it feels like we're not out of the woods yet with tech.
